segment.source: ms.ContentId: 8D89E9D8-2501-46A7-9304-2F19F37AFC85
segment.target: ms.ContentId: 8D89E9D8-2501-46A7-9304-2F19F37AFC85

segment.source: title: Working with checkpoints
segment.target: title: Working with checkpoints

segment.source: Using checkpoints to revert virtual machines to a previous state
segment.target: Using checkpoints to revert virtual machines to a previous state

segment.source: 24-Nov update, part1.
segment.target: 24-Nov update, part1.

segment.source: Test update for Demo.
segment.target: Test update for Demo.

segment.source: Adding this sentence for testing HO-HB process.
segment.target: Adding this sentence for testing HO-HB process.

segment.source: Checkpoints provide a fast and easy way to revert the virtual machine to a previous state.
segment.target: Checkpoints provide a fast and easy way to revert the virtual machine to a previous state.

segment.source: This is especially helpful when you are about to make a change to a virtual machine and you want to be able to roll-back to the present state if that change cause issues.
segment.target: This is especially helpful when you are about to make a change to a virtual machine and you want to be able to roll-back to the present state if that change cause issues.

segment.source: Enable or disable checkpoints
segment.target: Enable or disable checkpoints

segment.source: In Hyper-V Manager, right-click the name of the virtual machine, and click Settings.
segment.target: In Hyper-V Manager, right-click the name of the virtual machine, and click Settings.

segment.source: In the Management section, select Checkpoints.
segment.target: In the Management section, select Checkpoints.

segment.source: To allow checkpoints to be taken off this virtual machine, make sure Enable Checkpoints is selected -- this is the default behavior.
segment.target: To allow checkpoints to be taken off this virtual machine, make sure Enable Checkpoints is selected -- this is the default behavior.

segment.source: To disable checkpoints, deselect the Enable Checkpoints check box.
segment.target: To disable checkpoints, deselect the Enable Checkpoints check box.

segment.source: Click Apply to apply your changes.
segment.target: Click Apply to apply your changes.

segment.source: If you are done, click OK to close the dialog box.
segment.target: If you are done, click OK to close the dialog box.

segment.source: Choose standard or production checkpoints
segment.target: Choose standard or production checkpoints

segment.source: There are two types of checkpoints:
segment.target: There are two types of checkpoints:

segment.source: Production checkpoints -- Used mainly on servers in production environments as a form of backup.
segment.target: Production checkpoints -- Used mainly on servers in production environments as a form of backup.

segment.source: Standard checkpoints -- Used in development or testing environments to allow rollback if a change fails.
segment.target: Standard checkpoints -- Used in development or testing environments to allow rollback if a change fails.

segment.source: Both types of checkpoints restore a virtual machine to a previous state.
segment.target: Both types of checkpoints restore a virtual machine to a previous state.

segment.source: Production checkpoints create an application-consistent checkpoint of a virtual machine.
segment.target: Production checkpoints create an application-consistent checkpoint of a virtual machine.

segment.source: That means the saved virtual machine will resume with no application state.
segment.target: That means the saved virtual machine will resume with no application state.

segment.source: Standard checkpoints (formerly known as snapshots) capture the exact memory state of your virtual machine.
segment.target: Standard checkpoints (formerly known as snapshots) capture the exact memory state of your virtual machine.

segment.source: That means the virtual machine will restore with exactly the same state in which the checkpoint was taken down to the exact application state.
segment.target: That means the virtual machine will restore with exactly the same state in which the checkpoint was taken down to the exact application state.

segment.source: Standard checkpoints may contain information about client connections, transactions, and the external network state.
segment.target: Standard checkpoints may contain information about client connections, transactions, and the external network state.

segment.source: This information may not be valid when the checkpoint is applied.
segment.target: This information may not be valid when the checkpoint is applied.

segment.source: Additionally, if a checkpoint is taken during an application crash, restoring that checkpoint will be in the middle of that crash.
segment.target: Additionally, if a checkpoint is taken during an application crash, restoring that checkpoint will be in the middle of that crash.

segment.source: The presence of a standard checkpoint for a virtual machine may impact the disk performance of the virtual machine.
segment.target: The presence of a standard checkpoint for a virtual machine may impact the disk performance of the virtual machine.

segment.source: We do not recommend using standard checkpoints on virtual machines when performance or the availability of storage space is critical.
segment.target: We do not recommend using standard checkpoints on virtual machines when performance or the availability of storage space is critical.

segment.source: Applying a production checkpoint involves booting the guest operating system from an offline state.
segment.target: Applying a production checkpoint involves booting the guest operating system from an offline state.

segment.source: This means that no application state or security information is captured as part of the checkpoint process.
segment.target: This means that no application state or security information is captured as part of the checkpoint process.

segment.source: The following table shows when to use production checkpoints or standard checkpoints, depending on the state of the virtual machine.
segment.target: The following table shows when to use production checkpoints or standard checkpoints, depending on the state of the virtual machine.

segment.source: Virtual Machine State
segment.target: Virtual Machine State

segment.source: Production Checkpoint
segment.target: Production Checkpoint

segment.source: Standard Checkpoint
segment.target: Standard Checkpoint

segment.source: Running with Integration Services
segment.target: Running with Integration Services

segment.source: Yes
segment.target: Yes

segment.source: Yes
segment.target: Yes

segment.source: Running without Integration Services
segment.target: Running without Integration Services

segment.source: No
segment.target: No

segment.source: Yes
segment.target: Yes

segment.source: Offline - no saved state
segment.target: Offline - no saved state

segment.source: Yes
segment.target: Yes

segment.source: Yes
segment.target: Yes

segment.source: Offline - with saved state
segment.target: Offline - with saved state

segment.source: No
segment.target: No

segment.source: Yes
segment.target: Yes

segment.source: Paused
segment.target: Paused

segment.source: No
segment.target: No

segment.source: Yes
segment.target: Yes

segment.source: To see the difference between Standard and Production checkpoints, look at the checkpoints walkthrough.
segment.target: To see the difference between Standard and Production checkpoints, look at the checkpoints walkthrough.

segment.source: Set a default checkpoint type
segment.target: Set a default checkpoint type

segment.source: In Hyper-V Manager, right-click the name of the virtual machine, and click Settings.
segment.target: In Hyper-V Manager, right-click the name of the virtual machine, and click Settings.

segment.source: In the Management section, select Checkpoints.
segment.target: In the Management section, select Checkpoints.

segment.source: Select either production checkpoints or standard checkpoints.
segment.target: Select either production checkpoints or standard checkpoints.

segment.source: If you choose production checkpoints, you can also specify whether the host should take a standard checkpoint if a production checkpoint cannot be taken.
segment.target: If you choose production checkpoints, you can also specify whether the host should take a standard checkpoint if a production checkpoint cannot be taken.

segment.source: If you clear this check box and a production checkpoint cannot be taken, no checkpoint will be selected.
segment.target: If you clear this check box and a production checkpoint cannot be taken, no checkpoint will be selected.

segment.source: If you want to change the location where the configuration files for the checkpoint are stored, change the path in the Checkpoint File Location section.
segment.target: If you want to change the location where the configuration files for the checkpoint are stored, change the path in the Checkpoint File Location section.

segment.source: Click Apply to apply your changes.
segment.target: Click Apply to apply your changes.

segment.source: If you are done, click OK to close the dialog box.
segment.target: If you are done, click OK to close the dialog box.

segment.source: The default behavior in Windows 10 for new virtual machines is to create production checkpoints with fallback to standard checkpoints
segment.target: The default behavior in Windows 10 for new virtual machines is to create production checkpoints with fallback to standard checkpoints

segment.source: Create a checkpoint
segment.target: Create a checkpoint

segment.source: To create a checkpoint
segment.target: To create a checkpoint

segment.source: In Hyper-V Manager, under Virtual Machines, select the virtual machine.
segment.target: In Hyper-V Manager, under Virtual Machines, select the virtual machine.

segment.source: Right-click the name of the virtual machine, and then click Checkpoint.
segment.target: Right-click the name of the virtual machine, and then click Checkpoint.

segment.source: When the process is complete, the checkpoint will appear under Checkpoints in the Hyper-V Manager.
segment.target: When the process is complete, the checkpoint will appear under Checkpoints in the Hyper-V Manager.

segment.source: Apply a checkpoint
segment.target: Apply a checkpoint

segment.source: If you want to revert your virtual machine to a previous point-in-time, you can apply an existing checkpoint.
segment.target: If you want to revert your virtual machine to a previous point-in-time, you can apply an existing checkpoint.

segment.source: In Hyper-V Manager, under Virtual Machines, select the virtual machine.
segment.target: In Hyper-V Manager, under Virtual Machines, select the virtual machine.

segment.source: In the Checkpoints section, right-click the checkpoint that you want to use and click Apply.
segment.target: In the Checkpoints section, right-click the checkpoint that you want to use and click Apply.

segment.source: A dialog box appears with the following options:
segment.target: A dialog box appears with the following options:

segment.source: Delete a checkpoint
segment.target: Delete a checkpoint

segment.source: To cleanly delete a checkpoint:
segment.target: To cleanly delete a checkpoint:

segment.source: In Hyper-V Manager, select the virtual machine.
segment.target: In Hyper-V Manager, select the virtual machine.

segment.source: In the Checkpoints section, right-click the checkpoint that you want to delete, and click Delete.
segment.target: In the Checkpoints section, right-click the checkpoint that you want to delete, and click Delete.

segment.source: You can also delete a checkpoint and all subsequent checkpoints.
segment.target: You can also delete a checkpoint and all subsequent checkpoints.

segment.source: To do so, right-click the earliest checkpoint that you want to delete, and then click ****Delete Checkpoint** Subtree**.
segment.target: To do so, right-click the earliest checkpoint that you want to delete, and then click ****Delete Checkpoint** Subtree**.

segment.source: You might be asked to verify that you want to delete the checkpoint.
segment.target: You might be asked to verify that you want to delete the checkpoint.

segment.source: Confirm that it is the correct checkpoint, and then click Delete.
segment.target: Confirm that it is the correct checkpoint, and then click Delete.

segment.source: The .avhdx and .vhdx files will merge, and when complete, the .avhdx file will be deleted from the file system.
segment.target: The .avhdx and .vhdx files will merge, and when complete, the .avhdx file will be deleted from the file system.

segment.source: Tip: You can use Windows Powershell to delete a checkpoint by using the Remove-VMSnapshot cmdlet.
segment.target: Tip: You can use Windows Powershell to delete a checkpoint by using the Remove-VMSnapshot cmdlet.

segment.source: Checkpoints are stored as .avhdx files in the same location as the .vhdx files for the virtual machine.
segment.target: Checkpoints are stored as .avhdx files in the same location as the .vhdx files for the virtual machine.

segment.source: You should not delete the .avhdx files directly.
segment.target: You should not delete the .avhdx files directly.

segment.source: Change where checkpoint settings and save state files are stored
segment.target: Change where checkpoint settings and save state files are stored

segment.source: If the virtual machine has no checkpoints, you can change where the checkpoint configuration and saved state files are stored.
segment.target: If the virtual machine has no checkpoints, you can change where the checkpoint configuration and saved state files are stored.

segment.source: In Hyper-V Manager, right-click the name of the virtual machine, and click Settings.
segment.target: In Hyper-V Manager, right-click the name of the virtual machine, and click Settings.

segment.source: In the Management section, select Checkpoints or Checkpoint File Location.
segment.target: In the Management section, select Checkpoints or Checkpoint File Location.

segment.source: In Checkpoint File Location, enter the path to the folder where you would like to store the files.
segment.target: In Checkpoint File Location, enter the path to the folder where you would like to store the files.

segment.source: Click Apply to apply your changes.
segment.target: Click Apply to apply your changes.

segment.source: If you are done, click OK to close the dialog box.
segment.target: If you are done, click OK to close the dialog box.

segment.source: The default location for storing checkpoint configuration files is: %systemroot%\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\Hyper-V\Snapshots.
segment.target: The default location for storing checkpoint configuration files is: %systemroot%\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\Hyper-V\Snapshots.

segment.source: Rename a checkpoint
segment.target: Rename a checkpoint

segment.source: In Hyper-V Manager, select the virtual machine.
segment.target: In Hyper-V Manager, select the virtual machine.

segment.source: Right-click the checkpoint, and then select Rename.
segment.target: Right-click the checkpoint, and then select Rename.

segment.source: Enter in the new name for the checkpoint.
segment.target: Enter in the new name for the checkpoint.

segment.source: It must be less than 100 characters, and the field cannot be empty.
segment.target: It must be less than 100 characters, and the field cannot be empty.

segment.source: Click ENTER when you are done.
segment.target: Click ENTER when you are done.

segment.source: By default, the name of a checkpoint is the name of the virtual machine combined with the date and time the checkpoint was taken.
segment.target: By default, the name of a checkpoint is the name of the virtual machine combined with the date and time the checkpoint was taken.

segment.source: This is the standard format:
segment.target: This is the standard format:

segment.source: Names are limited to 100 characters or less, and the name cannot be blank.
segment.target: Names are limited to 100 characters or less, and the name cannot be blank.
